content:
Great playground @Timinator!
Decided to give it a go with the puzzle https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/who-dunnit as end target (can't get more than 85% on it with my current approach).

I Painfully translated the DLX algorithm to C++ and I can now confidently say it almost works :').
I pass all but validator 6, test case 7, and validator 7 on this puzzle, which seems like a tomorrow problem to me.

Cheers.

EDIT: nevermind, it works (problem was I didn't yield).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The playground needs completion

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle and playground. Clearly a lot of work went into making these.

It was good fun, I ended up solving it with both DLX in rust and a SAT solver in python.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I used the algorithm described in the tutorial and solved the first part. Very instructive. Thank you.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I followed the tutorial and solved part I. It seems very well described. 
considering that the algorithm is presented in the tutorial and that in part I it is only necessary to parse the input according to the rules, perhaps the difficulty could be easy?
Thank you!

I agree 100%. I had this puzzle labeled as easy for the past 6 months and then I second guessed myself right before changing to WIP. For now, I am going to flip it back to easy and see if anybody makes a case for why it should maybe be medium.

Great choice of puzzle! The Who Dunnit? puzzle, maybe more than any other puzzle I cover in the playground, displays a crazy difficulty discrepancy between finding a solution with Algorithm X and finding a solution without Algorithm X.

I concur, just solved it under 15 minutes with the algo where I couldn't solve it without.

Thanks for this playground, I really appreciate it.
Good catch! I checked my Sudoku Solver solution and I don't have it there. It has been removed. I believe my solver that first tries to solve all grids logically stores the grid as an attribute.

I don't think this puzzle should be easy... I've had to spend considerable amount of time rewriting the AlgoX to Kotlin and reading your tutorial. (and now found, that 3 testcases not yielding result for me, so I have a bug somewhere)

I have struggled with this for quite a while. It is probably only easy if one uses the given Python solver. There is nothing easy about translating the solver to another language, especially getting the DLX part correct. I may need to consider adding an additional comment to cover:

1) Easy is probably an appropriate classification for somebody that uses the provided Python solver and follows the tutorial.

2) Medium is probably appropriate for somebody that implements a backtracking solution other than Algorithm X.

3) Medium, at least, or even hard might be appropriate for somebody taking on the task of translating the solver to another language.
I've convinced myself, medium is the correct classification in general (I've gotten lazy with Python) :-)
